item.title: Final Fantasy 7 Remake: Best Mods For Cloud
item.description:
Summary

  • The Playable Zack mod allows gamers to experience Final Fantasy 7 with Zack instead of Cloud.
  • The Cloud Sephiroth Outfit mod gives Cloud a villainous look.
  • The Cloud Hyper HD Texture Pack enhances Cloud's appearance with 8k textures for a more detailed look.

Cloud Strife is one of the most recognizable video game protagonists, playing a huge part in the large and intricate story of the Final Fantasy 7 compilation series. His influence on the series and gaming as a whole is undeniable, so it’s no surprise that there are plenty of Final Fantasy 7 Remake mods available that revolve solely around him.

Most of the mods for Cloud–and the other characters in the game–are cosmetic, focusing on changing different aspects of his appearance, such as eye and hair color or the style of his outfit. Some mods make changes to Cloud’s gameplay mechanics, but most of these mod types focus on multiple characters rather than just Cloud himself. For those looking to spice up their playthrough, here are some of the best Cloud mods for Final Fantasy 7 Remake .

8 Playable Zack Over Cloud

Over 5,200 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by Jujub

Zack Fair is a popular character in the Final Fantasy 7 series, and he appears as a supporting character in the remake of Final Fantasy 7 . This mod replaces Cloud’s model with Zack’s model, allowing players to feel like they are playing through the campaign with Zack as the protagonist instead.

This is a must-try mod for those who are particularly fond of Zack as a character. It’s also well-suited for players who wish Zack had a more significant role to play in the remake or those who would have liked to have seen him have more scenes with Aerith.

7 Cloud Sephiroth Outfit

Over 7,600 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by Ninjagrime

For those who like the idea of a villainous Cloud, the Cloud Sephiroth Outfit mod is a great option. It gives Cloud the outfit of Sephiroth, the big bad in Final Fantasy 7 and one of the most iconic video game villains of all time.

There isn’t much more to the mod than that, but it’s still pretty fun to play around with the idea of an evil version of Cloud, especially since Rebirth touches on it in a few significant scenes.

6 Cloud Hyper HD Texture Pack

Over 18,200 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by SweetFluff3D

The Cloud Hyper HD Texture Pack mod increases the quality of Cloud’s visuals significantly, creating crisper and clearer textures. The mod overhauls the textures of Cloud’s standard outfit and remasters them in 8k resolution.

This results in a huge difference regarding Cloud’s look, making all the little details in his clothing come to life even more so. The handcrafted nature of the mod also makes it particularly impressive to behold.

5 Gorgeous Dress Cloud

Over 6,000 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by Adol

One of the more memorable moments in the Final Fantasy 7 Remake is when Cloud goes undercover, dressed as a woman, while trying to get up close and personal with Don Corneo, the head of the organized crime syndicate in Midgar. There are three different dresses that Cloud can wear, and the player's choices in side missions will be the deciding factor as to which one he dons. That said, one of the more elegant dresses is a lavender ball gown with black trims. This mod allows players to dress Cloud in that lavender gown for the whole game.

Cloud looks surprisingly stunning in the outfit, so why not let him be a fancy princess for an extended period? This mod is truly a must for those who wished the dress-up segments lasted a little longer.

4 Cloud Advent Children Outfit

Over 71,700 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by Ninjagrime

Final Fantasy 7: Advent Children is an animated film that takes place two years after the original Final Fantasy 7 game. It’s a popular movie that was released in 2005 and garnered much attention from Final Fantasy fans, so it is no surprise that there are mods that dress up the characters in the remake with their outfits from the film.

This particular mod switches Cloud’s outfit to the clothes he wears in Advent Children . Fans of the movie can also pair it with mods that change the outfits of the other characters to the ones they wear in movie, allowing every character to cosplay as their future counterparts.

3 Lv.99 Mod

Over 27,500 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by Altezein

The Lv.99 Mod applies to both Cloud and his companions in the Final Fantasy 7 Remake . It lets players rank up past the maximum level 50, allowing them to level up all the way to level 99. Parameter limits can also be broken, such as limits on spirit and defense levels. This can make gameplay and combat a little too easy, but other mods can be used to balance things out for those who still want to be challenged.

An optional file is also included in the mod that gives players the chance to add other features, such as a mod including enemies that are also level 99 in Hard Mode or a mod that removes the red low HP screen warning.

2 EverCrisis Cloud

Over 13,000 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by Ninjagrime

Final Fantasy 7: Ever Crisis is a mobile gacha game that retells events from Final Fantasy 7 and all canon media within the Final Fantasy 7 compilation. Released in September 2023, it had around 7 million downloads by November of the same year. It’s safe to say that it’s relatively popular, so it isn’t surprising that there are mods that dress the characters of Remake in their outfits from Ever Crisis .

This mod replaces Cloud’s regular outfit with the one that he wears in the mobile game. For those who enjoy both the remake and the Ever Crisis , this mod allows them to create their own mini-crossover.

1 Cloud Kingdom Hearts Outfit

Over 28,000 Downloads

  • Mod link
  • Created by ColossalCake

Cloud appears in the popular Kingdom Hearts game series, which is a crossover between Disney and Final Fantasy . He acts as a supporting character in Kingdom Hearts and features in several games.

His most distinctive look during his time in Kingdom Hearts is his attire from the first entry, which includes a red scarf/cape that covers the lower half of his face, a black wing located on his back, and bandages tied around his sword. This mod recreates the Kingdom Hearts 1 look in Remake perfectly, creating a style for Cloud that both Final Fantasy and Kingdom Hearts fans alike can enjoy.

item.title: Civilization 7: How to Complete the Enlightenment Legacy Path
item.description:
In Civilization 7 's Age of Exploration, the Enlightenment Legacy Path is one of four Legacy Paths available. Each focuses on a different style of play: Militaristic, Economic, Cultural, and Scientific. Completing Legacy Paths provides you with some fantastic bonuses in the next Age, and also guides you toward improving your civilization in whatever area that path is focused on.

In Civilization 7 's Age of Exploration, Enlightenment is the Scientific Legacy Path and tasks you with increasing tile yields to a certain total value. Your City Center tiles don't count for this, so you'll need to make careful use of Specialists and adjacency bonuses to get the yields necessary.

Ways to Raise Tile Yields in Civilization 7

It's best to use Urban Districts for this strategy, since they can take advantage of Adjacency Bonuses and Specialists to greatly increase yields. You'll want to build Districts with an eye for maximizing both building's adjacency bonuses. For example, Production Buildings and Science Buildings both benefit from adjacency to resources and Wonders, so building them on tiles surrounded by these would get you a huge head start.

You can then further enhance the yield per turn of the tile by assigning specialists to it since multiple specialists can be assigned to keep boosting gains further. You'll want to boost food output as much as possible to ensure your cities and towns grow quickly and thus generate more specialists.

How to Complete the Enlightenment Legacy Path in Civilization 7

To complete the Enlightenment Legacy Path, you'll need to have five tiles with 40+ total yield. This means the combined Science, Culture, Happiness, Food, and Production produced by that tile each turn.

As mentioned earlier, the easiest way to do this is by building two buildings on the tile that share adjacency bonus types, on a tile where they can take advantage of those bonuses, and then stack specialists on that tile to boost the yield up past 40. Once you've done this on five separate tiles, you'll have completed the Enlightenment Legacy Path.

item.title: Genshin Impact: Narukami Island Electroculus Locations
item.description:
Narukami Island in Genshin Impact is Inazuma's standout location, as it encompasses the vibrant culture of the nation and has a welcoming nature compared to the rest of war-torn Inazuma. Travelers can step foot in Inazuma City or make the long climb to the Grand Narukami Shrine to provide offerings to the Sakura Tree.

You can also collect a total of 38 Electroculus on Narukami Island. Obtaining some of these requires progression through certain quests and mechanics, while others can be tricky in their own ways. Therefore, this guide should help you discover and collect every Electroculus on Narukami Island.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 1

You can start collecting Electroculus on Narukami Island in Ritou and its outskirts, as they are very simple to spot. The first Electroculus can be found to the north of the Statue of the Seven. Before collecting this Electroculus, you will have to complete the "Ritou Escape Plan" objective in the Inazuma Archon Quest to explore the nation.

Once you have obtained the Ritou Travel Permit, the first Electroculus can be found to the north of the Statue of the Seven. Activate the Waverider waypoint and head towards the small group of islands. Climb to the top of the largest island and collect the Electroculus

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 2

Return to Ritou and climb the building in front of the Statue of the Seven to get to the Electrouclus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 3

Head towards the Konda Village teleport waypoint. On your way, you can spot a Thunder Barrier with an Electroculus inside it. Use an Electrogranum to go inside the Thunder Barrier and obtain the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 4

Go west from the northern Konda Village teleport waypoint to find an Electrogranum. Use it to reach the Electroculus high in the air.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 5

Climb the roof of the hut in Konda Village that has a pole with fish cutouts on it. The Electroculus can be found on top of the pole.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 6

Accessing this, and the next, Electroculus, requires starting the world quest, Sacred Sakura Cleansing Ritual. After enough progress, you will be able to unlock the well in Konda Village. Go inside the well and continue towards the shrine area. From here, take the right to find the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 7

The other Electroculus can be found by going inside a room that is blocked by two wooden boxes right before the Thunder Barrier. Use a small character to enter the tiny gap, and you will be able to collect the Electroculus in the room.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 8

Head towards Inazuma City. While on your way, you can spot an Electroculus on top of a rock that has a Precious Chest below it.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 9

Head to Amakane Island and reach the cliff to find an Electroculus on top of a cherry blossom tree.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 10

This Electroculus, found on the island to the left of Inazuma City, is a tricky one to collect as you cannot swim and obtain it. Instead, you will have to go up in the air and plunge directly on top of the Electroculus to get it. You can either use an Electrogranum or eject from the Waverider to gain enough height.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 11

This is another tricky Electroculus to obtain as the marker might lead you to believe it's on top of a building. However, you will have to go below Inazuma City, which houses a cave system. Enter the caves to find the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 12

This is one of the most frustrating Electroculus to obtain as it is on top of Tenshukaku. Climbing this is quite an ordeal, but the biggest challenge comes towards the end of the climb where there is a ledge that requires you to have a character like Zhongli, Geo Traveler, Kazuha, or gadgets like Wind Catcher.

Make sure to have your Traveler with the Geo element to easily complete this. Create a Geo construct with the Elemental Skill to gain an additional platform that can help you climb to the very top of Tenshukaku, which has the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 13

It's time to head into the heart of Narukami Island, starting with Chinju Forest. Go forward from the teleport waypoint to find the Electroculus on top of a monolith.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 14

Head deeper into Chinju Forest to find an Electroculus on top of Ioroi, a bake-danuki that is now a statue.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 15

Go to the Kamisato Estate and drop from the cliff to find the Electroculus in an alcove with a bake-danuki.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 16

Head towards Mount Yougou from the Kamisato Estate. Activate the Electrogranum to gain enough height to collect the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 17

From the broken bridges that form a path to the top of Mount Yougou, take a detour to reach the Court of Flowing Sand domain. Go east from the domain to find the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 18

Reach the Grand Narukami Shrine and climb the building to obtain this Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 19

Go down from the northern side of the Grand Narukami Shrine, where the Sacred Sakura tree is, to find a Thunder Barrier below. You will need to level up the Sacred Sakura Tree to Level 17 in order to collect the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 20

Glide down from the Grand Narukami Shrine teleport waypoint towards the waterfall below. The Electroculus can be found on one of the floating rocks near the waterfall.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 21

This Electroculus is easy to obtain as it is in front of a large shrine in the dark blue area of the map. You can also get this Electroculus by simply progressing through the Sacred Sakura Cleansing Ritual world quest.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 22

Return to the Grand Narukami Shrine waypoint and glide from the Sacred Sakura Tree. You can find the Electroculus on the mountain opposite Mount Yougou.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 23

The intended way to get this Electroculus is to find three Seelies nearby. However, you will need the Memento Lens, which is obtained from the Sacred Sakura Cleansing Ritual world quest. If you don't wish to complete significant portions of the quest, there is an alternative way to get this Electroculus.

Simply glide down from the Grand Narukami Shrine towards the location of the Electroculus. Once you get close, the Electroculus will appear in the air and can be obtained easily.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 24

Glide down from the Grand Narukami Shrine once again and go west to find the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 25

Continue towards the west until you reach a cliff with a large tree that has no leaves. Climb to the top to find the Electroculus. It is recommended to defeat the enemies in the area to have an easier time climbing the tree.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 26

From the previous location, glide down the cliff and head to the coast. You can spot a small cave that has a shrine as well as an Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 27

Head towards Araumi to find a Ruin Guard behind a Thunder Barrier as well as an Electroculus. You can simply climb the structure to find an open roof. This will allow you to get inside the room and collect the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 28

Go to the east of Araumi, near the Court of Flowing Sand domain, to find a waterfall that has an Electroculus at the bottom of it.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 29

To gain access to this Electroculus, you will require the Rust-Worn Key that can be found in Konda Village while doing the Sacred Sakura Cleansing Ritual. Once you get this key, head to the pond near the dark blue location on the map. You will find two passages, and one of them will be blocked by a metal door. Use the key to open the door and collect the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 30

Return to Araumi and head to the central structure to find an Electroculus floating above it.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 31

Go to the cliff in Araumi and go down to find the Electroculus right below the cliff.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 32

Go to the Kamisato Estate and head north until you find a couple of Kitsune Statues. The Electroculus can be found right next to them.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 33

You will need the Memento Lens to get this Electroculus in the intended way. However, you can glide towards the island from the Grand Narukami Shrine teleport waypoint. This will help you get enough height to collect the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 34

Obtaining this Electroculus requires reaching Level 17 in the Sacred Sakura Tree's Favor.

This is one of the more well-hidden Electroculus as it requires a set of puzzles to be solved. First, activate the four Electro Monuments in Araumi to go deeper inside the central structure. After this, you can spot an Electro Cube puzzle.

Solving the Electro Cube puzzle will allow you to lower the water and go underground. Swim to the end to find a button that completely lowers the water. There is another Electro Cube puzzle near this button that gives out a Precious Chest when solved.

You can now obtain the Electroculus by getting an Electrogranum and passing through the barrier.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 35

To find this Electroculus, you will have to go further underground until you come across a shipwreck nearby. Cross this area to find the Perpetual Mechanical Array boss arena. Glide over the arena to the other side to find the Electroculus.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 36

Getting the next three Electroculus requires progression through the Sacred Sakura Cleansing Ritual. Once you obtain the Memento Lens, head to the island closest to the Kamisato Estate Waverider waypoint.

Use the Memento Lens on the fox statue to reveal the Electroculus and a hidden passage.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 37

Go inside the hidden passage and reach its end to find a Seelie. Follow the Seelie and climb out of the passage to reach another island surrounded by a mysterious wind barrier. The Electroculus can be collected by climbing a tree and gliding from it.

Narukami Island Electroculus Location 38

The last Electroculus on Narukami Island can be collected after reaching the final part of the Sacred Sakura Cleansing Ritual. The electricity-infused lake at the bottom of Mount Yougou will open up and lead to an underground area. The Electroculus can be found as soon as the hole appears.

item.title: 8 Best Sewer Levels In Video Games, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Sewer levels in video games offer plenty of potential for horror and are easy to make, making them popular among game developers.
  • Levels like Killer Croc's Lair in Batman: Arkham Asylum and Clanker's Cavern in Banjo-Kazooie provide tense and memorable gameplay experiences.
  • Games like Dark Souls, The Elder Scrolls, Jak 2, Skyrim, and Mario Bros. feature unique sewer stages that contribute to gameplay and storytelling.

Despite being one of the most rancid, disgusting places to spend more than a second in on the entire planet, video games have (for some reason) had a long love affair with sewers. Something about sending their players to wade through putrid water in dark, confined spaces really lights up the average game developer's eyes.

It might have something to do with the horror potential and how easy it is to create a winding, labyrinthian tunnel system with copy-pasted assets. Whatever the case, there are now countless examples of sewer stages, and some games, the ones that have unique, memorable moments, eerie atmospheres, interesting geographies, or creative art behind them, have even managed to turn these excremental excursions into exciting experiences.

8 Killer Croc's Lair - Batman: Arkham Asylum

Delving Deep Into The Croc's Watery Hunting Ground

Few sewer levels are as tense as Killer Croc's lair in Batman: Arkham Asylum . The dimly lit tunnels, the eerie silence punctuated by Croc's growls, and the constant threat of being dragged into the murky depths would send a slimy tingle down any gadget-clad vigilante's spine.

Croc has conveniently (or inconveniently for Batman) made his underground lair right under the asylum, where the Caped Crusader needs to collect Titan spore samples for his antidote. The entire level has Batman sneaking around and countering Croc's snapping with a well-placed batarang to the throat in a tense game of bat and croc.

7 Clanker's Cavern - Banjo-Kazooie

Mouldy Crabs, Putrid Monsters, And A Rusty, Agonized Shark

It is hard to imagine Gruntilda the Witch having good hygiene habits, especially considering the state of Clanker's Cavern, Banjo-Kazooie 's mold-infested pool level containing many angry green crabs, floating trash, and a poor, agonized shark.

Clanker's place at the center of the watery garbage recycling center helps tie the level together. Helping Clanker with his toothache, freeing him from his chains, and taking care of the parasites in his stomach makes his cavern one of Banjo Kazooie's more memorable levels, even if it is gross to trudge around in.

6 The Depths - Dark Souls

Big Rats, Deadly Slime, And Cursed Gas

Any good, Gwyn-fearing chosen undead would appreciate that if the above-ground world is so wretched and ruined, running around an old sewer system couldn't be much worse. However, no matter how bleak things can seem at any given moment in Dark Souls , players can be sure they can and will get a lot worse. The Depths is one of those places.

Situated below Undead Burg, is not just a place to send unmentionables but those who have become societal trash as well. Thieves and cannibals share a living space with some of Dark Souls' most annoying enemies, including gelatinous slimes, curse-spreading basilisks, gigantic rats, and a mutated dragon descendant known as the Gaping Dragon, which looks as bad as it sounds.

5 Imperial Sewers - The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion

Starting Out In Cyrodiil From The Bottom (The Very Bottom)

Although it is hardly the most glamorous entrance into Cyrodiil, it is through its forgotten caves, eerie escape routes, and finally, a series of grandiose waste disposal flows, that the would-be Hero of Kvatch snatches their first glimmer of freedom. The Elder Scrolls games are famously replayable, and it is for this reason that most Oblivion fans will have the layout of this sewer-cum-secret passageway burnt into their minds.

These passageways return later if the player decides to explore their networks beneath the Imperial City. From the detritus found scattered all around, its citizens use the various sewer openings across the metropolis to dispose of all kinds of waste, including (for some reason) fresh cheese and vegetables, which the player character is free to consume, should they so wish.

4 Haven Sewers - Jak 2

From Scat Pit To Skate Park

With autonomous turrets, motion-detection lighting, water level controls, and elevators feature throughout, the sewers beneath the dystopian streets of Haven City in Jak 2 are surprisingly technologically advanced, considering their primary purpose, even if the lights occasionally flicker off mid-battle, with horrific results.

However, the coolest thing about this sludge slide is its potential as a skating (or, more accurately, a jetboard) arena. Half pipes, rails, ramps, and chutes make getting around a joy, and as an added bonus, the jetboard allows Jak to cross those pools of chunky water undampened.

3 The Ratway - The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

Those Thieves Went Went Rat-A-Away

Riften's Ratway in Skyrim is the coolest place the Thieves Guild could think of to put their headquarters, and as such, it is furnished with everything a secretive group of penny-pinchers would need to make their outfit a success: a lockpick and pickpocketing training area, storage, a bad, and beds (that are disgustingly close to open sewage).

These sewers are not just home to thieves, but to the mad, the lost, and the paranoid. Connected to the Ratway is the Ratway Warrens, an area that the Last Dragonborn must traverse as part of a main story mission. Only masters of stealth will slip by unnoticed, but a good axe arm or a potent destruction spell is highly recommended for the clumsy-footed urban explorer.

2 Every Phase - Mario Bros.

The Wonder Brothers Plumb Their First Pipes

While the series would be known for practically inventing the side-scrolling platformer, the original Mario Bros. arcade game is essentially a giant, looping sewer level, with the titular brothers battling enemies across a series of increasingly difficult phases.

Besides being one of the earliest examples of a sewer level in video game history, the endless phases depicting a sewer full of floating platforms and semi-aquatic pests was an important milestone in Mario 's history. It introduced many Mario staples, including flipping enemies, coins, and Shell Creepers (which would later be known as Koopa Troopas), and, perhaps most importantly, pipes.

1 The Eel Deal, Sewer Or Later, Hangin' Out - Crash Bandicoot 2: Cortex Strikes Back

The Stench Of The Sewers Never Sounded So Good

It would normally be difficult to get players excited for another dose of sewer sleuthing, regardless of the story or gameplay. However, one thing brings Crash fans back for more slopping and sliding in Crash Bandicoot 2: Cortex Strikes Back , and that's the catchy sewer-level music.

The metallic echo of pipes, the smooth industrial fry drops, dope bass, and the twangy tubulum pipe pluck make dodging the soap-sud robots, electrified water, and inexplicable lava tubes in "The Eel Deal," "Sewer or Later," and "Hangin' Out" a grand old time, despite the stink.

item.title: 10 Games About Feudal Japan to Check Out if You Liked Assassin's Creed Shadows
item.description:
Summary

  • Feudal Japan is a popular setting for video games, offering action-packed gameplay.
  • Some games set in feudal Japan focus more on stealth and tactics, rather than action.
  • Various games explore different historical periods in Japan, providing unique gameplay experiences.

A core part of a video game, or any story for that matter, is the setting. Fictional worlds are a dominant form of storytelling, yet creating a narrative that takes place in real-world history is just as viable. There is a lot of human history for any game to adapt, and Japanese history is one such domain that many games dabble in.

Feudal Japan has spawned many beloved and famous elements, from movies, to video games, to comics. The setting is a hotspot for action games, given the abundance of conflict during the period. However, there are also video games set in feudal Japan that don't involve as much action, but can still offer a great experience.

10 Rise Of The Ronin

Set During The 1800s

Team Ninja, as a Japanese company, has a history of making games associated with Japanese culture and elements. Rise of the Ronin takes place hundreds of years ago, during the 1800s.

Players can explore the open world using the normal weapons associated with Japan. The combat is fast-paced and action-oriented, as per usual for Team Ninja. The gameplay is like a combination of Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty/Nioh mixed with Ghost of Tsushima , fighting across the increasingly modernized landscape of Japan. Players can traverse the quieter countryside or the bustling urban areas.

9 Like A Dragon: Ishin!

Set During The 1860s

The Yakuza/Like a Dragon series is best known for taking place in contemporary Japan. Often set in Tokyo, the series also visits various other locations for the story's locale. However, Like a Dragon: Ishin! takes a different approach as a spin-off. It is set over a century ago, when Japan began to open up to the world.

As a result, there are various aspects of modernism as well as traditional Japanese elements. Most notably, players can use various swords, as well as firearms. It might not be as early in Japanese history compared to some other games, but it should be experienced for anyone looking for such a game.

8 Onimusha: Warlords

Set In The Sengoku Period

Capcom has a history of creating games with a fixed camera angle, and Onimusha: Warlords is another title to fall under this category. Set during Japan's Sengoku Period, Onimusha: Warlords plays like a combination of early Resident Evil and Devil May Cry games.

Players travel through tight, concise areas, with movement speed, item usage, and puzzles reminiscent of a Resident Evil game. The combat is mainly executed via melee, reminiscent of Devil May Cry's swordplay. Players battle against various types of enemies, ranging from easily defeated, to challenging adversaries. These enemies drop different souls that are used as money or as currency to upgrade weapons, or that can restore the player's resources.

7 Shadows Tactics: Blades Of The Shogun

Set After The Unification Of Japan

While feudal Japan might bring about connotations of the action genre, what with the samurai and warring, Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun is instead a real-time tactics game. Set in feudal Japan but after the unification of the country, the game revolves around a plot to dethrone the shogun and overthrow his rule.

The game involves various characters for the player to control, and the main gameplay mechanic is stealth. Each of the various characters has different abilities to use, varying from the kind that can kill enemies, to more support-based abilities, such as a disguise or distraction.

6 Nioh 1

Set During 1600

The first Nioh game has a unique approach to its story. Set in the year 1600, players don't play as a Japanese character, but as an Irish character. However, it is filled with the same high-octane action that other Team Ninja games are filled with.

Players fight their way through the game by facing human and yokai enemies, using a vast array of weaponry. The game has light elements from the soulslike subgenre, with dodging, stamina conservation, blocking, among others. This gameplay takes place in an alternate dark fantasy version of Japan, including notable historical Japanese figures. It's perfect for anyone who loves challenging, fast-paced action games.

5 Nioh 2

Set During The 1500s

The second Nioh game is a prequel, taking place before the first. Set in the 1500s, players journey through the Sengoku Era, meeting notable historical Japanese figures throughout.

The gameplay is similar to the first Nioh game, with fast-paced and high-octane action, fighting against numerous foes, be they human or yokai. There is a huge amount of weaponry to use, spanning across different weapon types, such as swords, spears, rifles, bows. For fans of feudal Japan, and especially those who enjoy Japanese mythology, Nioh 2 definitely deserves a playthrough.

4 Total War: Shogun 2

Set In The 16th Century

The Total War series has involved itself with different historical settings as part of its many games, with Japan being a location for some of the entries. Total War: Shogun 2 returns to Japan after the first game, and is played as a strategy game where players control their forces.

The gameplay features two distinct modes: one where players control their forces and land through turn-based strategy, and one where players control their forces directly via real-time tactics. Players have an array of elements to manage, including the construction of settlements, the prosperity of the economy, the continuation of the military, the growth of technology, and religious beliefs. Players play as one of the various clans, where they can unlock different military units to help further their success.

3 Sengoku Dynasty

Set In The Sengoku Period

There have been various games set in feudal Japan over the years, and Sengoku Dynasty deals in such a setting very directly. As stated in its name, Sengoku Dynasty is set in the Sengoku period, making for a prime game for anyone that wants to play something set in feudal Japan.

The main aspect of this game is the city building. Players can build a village, cultivate it, and see its prosperity. However, there is also combat across the open world that players can explore. It is also available in multiplayer, perfect for those that wish to attempt surviving feudal Japan in a group.

2 Ghost Of Tsushima

Set During The Mongol Invasion

The core premise of Ghost of Tsushima's plot and setting is the Mongol invasion of Japan. Attempting to first invade Japan by taking the island of Tsushima, the story involves the protagonist, Jin Sakai, attempting to fend off the Mongol forces by whatever means necessary.

The game lets players fight with numerous weapons, such as a katana, different bows, and various small tools called Ghost Weapons. Players can explore the island of Tsushima and accept quests, discover shrines, relax in hot springs, and generally appreciate the stunning beauty Sucker Punch managed to portray.

1 Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice

Set In A Fictionalized Sengoku Period

While not the most historically accurate portrayal of feudal Japan, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice still takes place hundreds of years ago in the country. Filled with Shinto and Buddhist symbolism, players will be tasked with exploring a region of Japan in order to complete a grand quest for the protagonist's master.

As a FromSoftware game, combat is a main focus. Players fight numerous human enemies, such as samurai and shinobi, as well as fictional beings, such as spirits and ogres. And of course, there are lots of bosses. The game portrays what historical Japan was like in a darker aspect. It is a grim and gloomy world, but one that still shows off the historical aspects of the country.
